entries.content: Never just offer a new perspective; don't fight with someone or try to convince them they're wrong when handling objections.
entries.notes: Relates to the principle behind Feel-Felt-Found/AAA - acknowledge first.

entries.content: "You know that that makes perfect sense, you know I I hear that a lot, I understand..."
entries.notes: Example of acknowledging/understanding the prospect's point (Feel/Listen/Acknowledge).

entries.content: Deal with the objection by reframing or reinforcing the prospect's own motivation.
entries.notes: Used after acknowledging, relates to the 'Found' part or Overcoming.

entries.content: Dig into objections like needing to talk to a spouse; don't dismiss them. Understand their perspective.
Get the prospect to have a conversation with you about their potential objections (e.g., what their spouse might say).
A man convinced against his will is of the same opinion still. Avoid strong-arming prospects into agreeing.
entries.notes: Relates to the goal of overcoming objections by getting prospect buy-in.

entries.content: Get the prospect to surrender or ask to meet, rather than begging for the appointment.
entries.notes: Relates to getting prospect buy-in after handling objections.

entries.content: Using a hypothetical scenario: 'Let's pretend you believed I had a solution and if we met, I could fix your problem. What would you want to do?'
entries.notes: Example technique to get the prospect to agree to the next step themselves after handling underlying concerns.
